data.name: BasePrivacyMainBody
data.value: Thank you downloading our mobile software. We will protect your Personal Information and your right to privacy. Any questions regarding your Personal Information, please contact us at service@CNGInternetSoftware.com This document will describe our privacy policy. We will explain to you what Information, if any, we collect, how it is (if received) used, and what your rights are. In case you do not agree with our Privacy Policy, please stop using this application. This privacy policy applies to all collected Information as well as related services.

data.name: BaseUserGuideBattery
data.value:
Good Question? Our Promise:
Our app will: 1) start timer and accelerometer only once the simulation page is up 2) stop all this the moment you leave the simulation 3) DO NOT have a timer and accelerometer just running in the background to be 'ready.'
Result? The CPR Simulation app uses just about 0.1% of battery power per hour of continous use.

data.name: BaseUserGuideDisplays
data.value:
To simulate the CPR activities we use the phone embedded 3-axis accelerometer, measuring all 3 'forces' of acceleration. It gives data-reads about 3,000 times a minute. Yes, VERY sensitive.
Two (of three) effects can be tested quickly. Tilt the device in every whatsoever direction a bit while the [CPR Simulator] screen is up, and a red display will tell you "No CPR - Not Flat -" (Press [Start Again] if needed). A tilted device is an incorrect device.
We installed software filters, accounting for this sensitive device. All filters are biased against a base line. Our filters are biased against the "Correct CPR" reading/display. Every time a "Correct" CPR is recorded, the next 8 CPR (out of 100 / min) recordings are marked as "Correct" if the reads fall within 25% (+-) of "Correct" CPR. This accounts for a events such as a shaky hand, a soft set of towels, a tilted (misreading) phone, etc. That makes the (biased) display for the very alert user a bit iffy.
Valid? We think so. Many 'first responders' like you and me performing CPR during an emergency that is not measured scientifically, and still, save the 'day.'

data.name: BaseUserGuideDoingCPR
data.value:
The top frame has (3) parts:
(1) Recording "Breath of Life" Rescue breathing is no longer required in layperson CPR emergencies. But. There are still emergency scenarios which call for rescue breathing. So, we simulate the count, and the Breathing Sets (30 CPR's each), and show the counters.
(2) A message telling you what your most current CPR compress (down push) would be in a real situation ("Correct," "Too Flat," i.e., not deep enough, or "Too Deep," i.e., a dangerously (2.4" +).
(3) A button to Save your CPR compression results in a DB.
The bottom frame has (2) parts:
(1) a line of two switches; (a) turning the beeper on/off; (b) turning the voice announcement for every 30 beeps on/off.
(2) A [ Start Again ] button. Pressing it will silence the sounds, reset the CPR counters, reset CPR results, and start from anew.

data.name: BaseUserGuidePillowsText51
data.value: Take a set of towels, pillows, something cushy to simulate a human chest. Fold your two hands, as shown in Pic. 1 on top of this 'chest'. Ready! Start the Simulation: 100 CPR compressions into the towels per minute, about 2.4 inches deep.

data.name: BaseUserGuidePillowsText53
data.value: 1) 'Officially?' OK, you remember the CPR 'hands' (Pic 1). The CPR-hands hold the edge of the phone (Pic 2). Run the app. The app will do the leading beeps (100/min), you do the compressions, it's all recorded, like "It's a-ok," or "No, not OK".

data.name: BaseUserGuidePillowsText531
data.value: 2) 'The-Easy-Way?' Still OK. Put just the lower CPR-hand flat on the towels, the phone on top; run the app, and do the compressions, the recordings.

data.name: BaseUserGuidePillowsText55
BaseUserGuidePillowsText56
data.value: Thankyou for you efforts to deepen you understanding of CPR.

data.name: BaseUserGuideResults
data.value:
[Best CPR Simulation]
The data in this section is from the list of saved CPR sessions, and is the best result measured against "correct CPR's."
Congratulation
Press [Share Option], and you can send an email to your friend that includes the data from the [Best CPR Simulation]. A little bragging, but hey, you did great.
The List of Results
A DB based list of all previous CPR sessions. Sorted by date. Press an individual record to have an option to delete that record.

data.name: BaseUserGuideResults1
data.value: Note: TAP a list-record to manage / DELETE that reocrd.

data.name: BaseUserGuideStart0
data.value: We are trying to simulate CPR compressions, record them, and maybe share the best result.

data.name: BaseUserGuideStart02
data.value: Simulating a human chest....... (1) Get a bunch of towels, pillows, a bunch of sweaters. The CPR's....... (2) Fold your hands resting on top of the towels / pillows / sweaters. See <How to Simulate...>, next pull-down.

data.name: BaseUserGuideStart04
data.value: (1) Have the phone in-between your hands. See <How to Simulate...>, next pull-down. (2) Start the app, using a thumb to control things (3) At each beep, you need to do a compression (about 2.4 inches, 100 a minute) (4) When it is time, press the [ Save Result ] button (5) Just in case you want to run another CPR session, press [ Start Again ]

data.name: BaseUserGuideStart06
data.value: The " Results " page shows: -- "Best CPR Simulation", allowing you to share your best CPR session result with a friend -- a list of all your CPR session results, sorted by date

data.name: BaseUserGuideWhatIsItText001
data.value: an audio and visual guide that trains you to do CPR compressions correctly. Correctly is 100 - 120 compressions per minute, about 2.4 inches deep (Adults)

data.name: BaseUserGuideWhatIsItText003
data.value: (1) The app beeps at a 100/min rate, and you should do a compress at every beep. (2) The app monitors your compression 'depth' and displays "Correct" for about 2.4\", "To Flat" for <2.4\", "Too Deep" for >2.4\" (3) At the end of a 'run' you can record the results. (4) The app allows you to text your best result to a friend.

data.name: BaseUserGuideWhatIsItText004
data.value: Please check [ How to simulate CPR Compressions ]

data.name: CPRResultWhyNot
data.value: Why not share this good news with a friend?
